snippet: Horses given the race-day medication furosemide bled at higher rates than those who were not, a study commissioned by the Breeders’ Cup found.
abstract: Study released by Breeders' Cup shows that horses treated with the race-day antibleeding medication furosemide bled at a greater rate than horses that did not receive the drug; about 95 percent of American thoroughbreds race on furosemide, drug first approved for race-day use in the mid-1970s and sold under the brand name Lasix.
lead_paragraph: Horses given the race-day medication furosemide bled at higher rates than those who were not, a study commissioned by the Breeders’ Cup found.

headline.main: Study Raises Questions About Antibleeding Drug
